title: Surfactant mediated enhanced biodegradation of hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH) isomers by Sphingomonas sp. NM05
abstract: Environmental biodegradation of several chlorinated pesticides is limited by their low solubility and sorption to soil surfaces. To mitigate this problem we quantified the effect of three biosurfactant viz., rhamnolipid, sophorolipid and trehalose-containing lipid on the dissolution, bioavailability, and biodegradation of HCH-isomers in liquid culture and in contaminated soil. The effect of biosurfactants was evaluated through the critical micelle concentration (CMC) value as determined for each isomer. The surfactant increased the solubilization of HCH isomers by 3-9 folds with rhamnolipid and sophorolipid being more effective and showing maximum solubilization of HCH isomers at 40 μg/mL, compared to trehalose-containing lipid showing peak solubilization at 60 μg/mL. The degradation of HCH isomers by Sphingomonas sp. NM05 in surfactant-amended liquid mineral salts medium showed 30% enhancement in 2 days as compared to degradation in 10 days in the absence of surfactant. HCH-spiked soil slurry incubated with surfactant also showed around 30-50% enhanced degradation of HCH which was comparable to the corresponding batch culture experiments. Among the three surfactants, sophorolipid offered highest solubilization and enhanced degradation of HCH isomers both in liquid medium and soil culture. The results of this study suggest the effectiveness of surfactants in improving HCH degradation by increased bioaccessibility.

motivations: Environmental biodegradation of chlorinated pesticides like hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH) is limited by their low solubility and sorption to soil surfaces.
There is a need to enhance the bioavailability and biodegradation of HCH isomers to mitigate their environmental impact.
objectives: Quantify the effect of biosurfactants on the dissolution, bioavailability, and biodegradation of HCH-isomers in liquid culture and contaminated soil.
Evaluate the effectiveness of different biosurfactants in enhancing HCH degradation by Sphingomonas sp. NM05.
methods: Use biosurfactants like rhamnolipid, sophorolipid, and trehalose-containing lipid to increase the solubilization of HCH isomers.
Conduct experiments in liquid culture and contaminated soil to assess the impact of biosurfactants on HCH degradation.
Measure the critical micelle concentration (CMC) value to determine the effectiveness of each biosurfactant.
results: Biosurfactants increased the solubilization of HCH isomers by 3-9 folds, with sophorolipid being the most effective.
Surfactant-amended media showed 30-50% enhanced degradation of HCH isomers in both liquid culture and soil experiments.
The use of biosurfactants improved the bioaccessibility and biodegradation of HCH isomers.
